body: For both AutoETS and AutoARIMA you can view AIC, BIC and HQIC (and anything else you need to know) via the summary method: `forecaster.summary()`. For AutoETS models you can also get them through `forecaster._fitted_forecaster.bic`
I was hoping I was able to retrieve parameter for evaulation. Of course I knew about the summary()

OK that makes sense - You need to do some digging to reach the fitted forecaster class from statsmodels etc.
Here is a summary on how to access them for a few of the classes: 
- **AutoETS:** `forecaster._fitted_forecaster.bic` relevant class is [ETSResults](https://www.statsmodels.org/dev/generated/statsmodels.tsa.exponential_smoothing.ets.ETSResults.html?highlight=etsresults#statsmodels.tsa.exponential_smoothing.ets.ETSResults) from statsmodels
- **ExponentialSmoothing:** `forecaster._fitted_forecaster.bic` relevant class is [HoltWintersResults](https://www.statsmodels.org/dev/generated/statsmodels.tsa.holtwinters.HoltWintersResults.html) from statsmodels
- **AutoARIMA:** `forecaster._forecaster.model_.arima_res_.bic` relevant class is [SARIMAXResults](https://www.statsmodels.org/dev/generated/statsmodels.tsa.statespace.sarimax.SARIMAXResults.html) from statsmodels
- **ARIMA:** `forecaster._forecaster.arima_res_.bic`relevant class is [SARIMAXResults](https://www.statsmodels.org/dev/generated/statsmodels.tsa.statespace.sarimax.SARIMAXResults.html) from statsmodels

Hope this helps.

But I think it should be possible using the commands as proposed initially - opening this back up hence.

I also think it´s a good first issue, since it just needs a loopthrough to `get_fitted_params` (plus documentation) which is straightforward to implement.

rename.from: Retrieving AIC, BIC and HQIC from any sktime models?
rename.to: Exposing AIC, BIC and HQIC from sktime models via get_fitted_params

body: (no need for you to do this, @zollen, but so that someone else can pick this up)
(how about you, @ltsaprounis :smiley: - you seem to know very well where all that stuff is)
Agree, sktime is a wrapper for all other forecasters, it would make sense to have a uniform interface for getting the fitting scores.

issue.title: Feature/information criteria get_fitted_params

repository.name: sktime
repository.description: A unified framework for machine learning with time series

issue.body:
<!--
Thanks for contributing a pull request! Please ensure you have taken a look
at our contribution guide: https://github.com/alan-turing-institute/sktime/blob/main/CONTRIBUTING.md
-->

#### Reference Issues/PRs
<!--
Example: Fixes #1234. See also #3456.

Please use keywords (e.g., Fixes) to create link to the issues or pull requests
you resolved, so that they will automatically be closed when your pull request
is merged. See https://github.com/blog/1506-closing-issues-via-pull-requests
-->
Fixes #931

#### What does this implement/fix? Explain your changes.
<!--
A clear and concise description of what you have implemented.
-->
Adding the available information criteria (AIC, AICc, BIC, HQIC) for various forecasting algorithms.
TBATS and BATS did not have a get_fitted_params method so I added it in the adapter there. Maybe we'll want to add additional parameters returned there. 

#### Does your contribution introduce a new dependency? If yes, which one?
No
<!--
If your contribution does add a new hard dependency, we may suggest to initially develop your contribution in a separate companion package in https://github.com/sktime/ to keep external dependencies of the core sktime package to a minimum.
-->

#### What should a reviewer concentrate their feedback on?

<!-- This section is particularly useful if you have a pull request that is still in development. You can guide the reviews to focus on the parts that are ready for their comments. We suggest using bullets (indicated by * or -) and filled checkboxes [x] here -->
Is get_fitted_params the right place to return those? maybe a similar function e.g. get_fit_results is more appropriate.

Thanks for contributing!

issue.title: [ENH] Nested `get_fitted_params` and `summary` interface

repository.name: sktime
repository.description: A unified framework for machine learning with time series

issue.body:
This is a feature suggestion arising from discussion in #877, #931, #942.

I suggest two new/refactored interface points:
* `summary` which is attached to `BaseObject` (as in post-merge #877)
* `get_fitted_params` which is attached to `sktime`'s (not `scikit-learn`'s) `BaseEstimator`

Update: it is probably better than the more convoluted suggestion below if the returns of both are `dict` and behave just like `get_params`. Any logic for retrieval should be provided in there, or a private version `_get_fitted_params`, rather than in "populate" functions.
 
---
Old API suggestion

Both should behave precisely like `scikit-learn`'s `get_params`, except that parameters are looked up in dedicated dictionaries `reports` and `fitted_params` rather than in self-attributes that correspond to `__init__` named arguments.

`fit` or `__init__` could populate these dictionaries, this could happen by `_populate_fitted_params` and `_populate_summary` private interfaces called at the end of `fit` (the non-private with the "plumbing" logic), which is specific to individual estimators/objects, or directly in `_fit` (not sure which is the better convention?).

For functionality, I think we can copy-paste `scikit-learn`'s `get_params` code here, and adapt it by making the change in where parameters are being retrieved. This would ensure nested access, which for example `get_fitted_params` doesn't have at current.

What do you think?
@mloning, @aiwalter, @RNKuhns, @ltsaprounis
